newsitem.title: USA: U.S. money managers more optimistic on debt-survey.
newsitem.headline: U.S. money managers more optimistic on debt-survey.

text.p: U.S. money managers were more bullish with their debt portfolios over the past week, slightly increasing their duration exposure, according to an MCM MoneyWatch Inc survey.
Durations as a percentage of benchmark inched up to 108.2 percent in the week ended August 4, from 108.1 in the previous week.
A duration reading above 100 percent indicates the group of investors polled is mostly long on the market.
A portfolio's duration represents its average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
In addition, cash levels fell and mortgages weighting continued to flag, said MCM MoneyWatch economist Astrid Adolfson, who conducts the weekly survey.
Cash as a percentage of assets fell to 3.19 percent from 3.24 percent registered the previous week.
In the "next likely move" category, portfolio managers representing 40 percent of total assets in the survey indicated they would "buy," down from 41 percent the prior week.
Strategists leaning toward "sell" rose to 11 percent from 10 percent the previous week.
Forty-nine percent of managers said they were "neutral" on the market, unchanged from the prior week.

Thirty-eight percent of investors polled overweighted the 10-plus years duration sector, down from 41 percent in the previous week. Seven percent underweighted the sector for the third consecutive week, while the remaining 55 percent were "neutral."
In the five- to 10-year duration sector, 42 percent of investors polled said they overweighted the securities and 20 percent underweighted them.
The survey included 38 domestic participants who manage about $110 billion in fixed-income assets. The poll is conducted weekly by MCM and usually is released on Tuesday.
